answers.text: The Industrial Revolution in the Midlands and Northern England spelled the end for most of Somerset's cottage industries

qas.question: What flourished in Somerset after the Industrial revelotuion
What Industry was important in the late 18th and 19th century of North Somerset

answers.text: Coal mining was an important industry in north Somerset

qas.question: What did the west somerset mineral way transport

answers.text: iron ore in the late 19th century; this was taken by the West Somerset Mineral Railway to Watchet Harbour for shipment to the furnaces at Ebbw Vale

qas.question: In what year did coal mining begin in Somerset?
How was coal shipped from the Somerset Coalfield?
In what year did the Bath and West of England Society for the Encouragement of Agriculture, Arts, Manufactures and Commerce shut down?
In what year was the Somerset Coalfield established?

context: <a0_0>The Industrial Revolution in the Midlands and Northern England spelled the end for most of Somerset's cottage industries<a0_0/>. <a1_0>Farming continued to flourish<a1_0/>, however, and the Bath and West of England Society for the Encouragement of Agriculture, Arts, Manufactures and Commerce was founded in <b4_0>1777<b4_0/> to improve farming methods. Despite this, 20 years later <b5_0>John Billingsley<b5_0/> conducted a survey of the county's agriculture in <b8_0>1795<b8_0/> and found that agricultural methods could still be improved. <a2_0>Coal mining was an important industry in north Somerset<a2_0/> during the 18th and 19th centuries, and by <b7_0>1800<b7_0/> it was prominent in Radstock. The Somerset Coalfield reached its peak production by the 1920s, but all the pits have now been closed, the last in 1973. Most of the surface buildings have been removed, and apart from a winding wheel outside Radstock Museum, little evidence of their former existence remains. Further west, the Brendon Hills were mined for <a3_0>iron ore in the late 19th century; this was taken by the <b6_0>West Somerset Mineral Railway<b6_0/> to Watchet Harbour for shipment to the furnaces at Ebbw Vale<a3_0/>.
